tit.cmt: 頭文字を大文字に変更

sen.j: 磐撞別命（いわつくわけのみこと、生没年不詳）は、記紀などに伝える古墳時代初期の皇族（王族）。
sen.e: Iwatsukuwake no mikoto (磐撞別命: year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who was said to be living during the early Kofun period (tumulus period), according to the historical documents such as "Kojiki " (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
sen.cmt: 名前の漢字表記を入れました。 記紀など→統一用語ではthe historical documents such as the Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan)とするよう指示がありましたが、書物初出のため、the historical documents such as "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan) と他の書物同様の扱いにしました。
sen.e: Iwatsukuwake no mikoto (磐撞別命: year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who lived during the early Kofun period (tumulus period) according to the historical documents such as the "Kojiki " (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).
sen.cmt: "Kojiki""Nihonshoki"の前にthe追加、who was said to be living→who livedとし、カンマ削除
sen.e: Iwatsukuwake no mikoto (磐撞別命: year of birth and death unknown) was a member of the Imperial family (Royal family), who lived during the early Kofun period (tumulus period) according to the historical documents such as the "Kojiki " (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the "Nihonshoki" (Chronicles of Japan).

sen.j: 磐衝別命、磐撞別皇子、石衝別王・伊波都久和気とも。
sen.e: His name (Iwatsukuwake) was also written as 磐衝別命, 磐撞別皇子, 石衝別王, 伊波都久和気, among others.
sen.cmt: 名前の漢字表記についての記述なので漢字を入れました。
sen.e: His name (Iwatsukuwake) was also written as 磐衝別命, 磐撞別皇子, 石衝別王, 伊波都久和気, among others.
His name (Iwatsukuwake) was also written as 磐衝別命, 磐撞別皇子, 石衝別王, 伊波都久和気, among others.

sen.j: 第11代垂仁天皇の第10皇子、母は山背大国不遅の娘・綺戸辺（かむはたとべ、弟苅羽田刀弁）。
sen.e: He is the tenth Imperial Prince of the eleventh Emperor Suinin, and his mother was the daughter of Yamashirookuni no Fuchi, Kamuhatatobe (written as 綺戸辺 or 弟苅羽田刀弁).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。 綺戸辺（かむはたとべ、弟苅羽田刀弁）Kamuhatatobe→名前の漢字表記を入れました。kanihatatobeとも言われているようです。
sen.e: He was the tenth prince of the eleventh Emperor Suinin, and his mother was the daughter of Yamashirookuni no Fuchi, Kamuhatatobe (written as 綺戸辺 or 弟苅羽田刀弁).
He was the tenth prince of the eleventh Emperor Suinin, and his mother was the daughter of Yamashirookuni no Fuchi, Kamuhatatobe (written as 綺戸辺 or 弟苅羽田刀弁).

sen.j: 同母妹に両道入姫命（ふたじいりひめのみこと、石衝毘売命。仲哀天皇の母）がいる。
sen.e: He had a maternal half sister, called Futajiirihime no mikoto (written as 両道入姫命 or 石衝毘売命), who became the mother of Emperor Chuai).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処。両道入姫命（ふたじいりひめのみこと、石衝毘売命）→Futajiirihime no mikoto (written as 両道入姫命 or 石衝毘売命)：名前の漢字表記を入れました。
sen.e: He had a maternal half sister, called Futajiirihime no mikoto (written as 両道入姫命 or 石衝毘売命), who became the mother of Emperor Chuai).
He had a maternal half sister, called Futajiirihime no mikoto (written as 両道入姫命 or 石衝毘売命), who became the mother of Emperor Chuai).

sen.j: 子に磐城別命（石城別王・伊波智和気）がおり、羽咋君、三尾君の祖とされる。
sen.e: He had a son named Iwakiwake no mikoto (in addition to 磐城別命, also written as 石城別王 and 伊波智和気), and he was said to be the ancestor of Hakui no kimi and Mio no kimi.
sen.cmt: 磐城別命（石城別王・伊波智和気）→Iwakiwake no mikoto (in addition to 磐城別命, also written as 石城別王 and 伊波智和気)（石城別王・伊波智和気）と名前の漢字表記を入れました
sen.e: He had a son named Iwakiwake no mikoto (in addition to 磐城別命, also written as 石城別王 and 伊波智和気), and it is said that he was the ancestor of Hakui no kimi and Mio no kimi.
sen.cmt: he was said to be the ancestor→it is said that he was the ancestorとしました。
sen.e: He had a son named Iwakiwake no mikoto (in addition to 磐城別命, also written as 石城別王 and 伊波智和気), and it is said that he was the ancestor of Hakui no kimi and Mio no kimi.

sen.j: 「上宮記」逸文によれば、その5世孫の振媛命は彦主人王に嫁ぎ、継体天皇を生んだ。
sen.e: According to the itsubun (unknown or lost writings) of "Jogiki" (Record of the Crown Prince), his fifth generation granddaughter, Furihime no mikoto got married with Hikoushio, and had a son, who later became Emperor Keitai.

According to the itsubun (unknown or lost writings) of 'Joguki' (Record of the Crown Prince), his fifth generation granddaughter, Furihime no mikoto got married with Hikoushio, and had a son, who later became Emperor Keitai.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更、Jogiki→Jogukiに修正
sen.e: According to the itsubun (unknown or lost writings) of 'Joguki' (Record of the Crown Prince), his fifth generation granddaughter, Furihime no mikoto got married with Hikoushio, and had a son, who later became Emperor Keitai.

sen.j: 『先代旧事本紀』「天皇本紀」では丹波道主王の娘・真砥野媛と垂仁天皇の間に生まれ、稲別命と兄弟とされ、また「国造本紀」では羽咋国造・加我国造の祖とされる。
sen.e: In the part of 'Tennohonki' (Records of emperors) of a text of Japanese histories "Sendaikujihongi," he (Emperor Keitai) was born between Tanbanomichinoshi no kimi's daughter, Matonohime, and Emperor Suinin, and he was said to be the brother of Inawake no mikoto, and in the part of 'Kokuzohonki' (Records of kuni no miyatsuko [local lords]), he was said to be the ancestor of Hakuinokuni no miyatsuko (local lord of the Hakui Province) and Kaganokuni no miyatsuko local lord of Kaga Province).
sen.cmt: 羽咋国造→Hakuinokuni no miyatsuko (local lord of the Hakui Province)と（）の説明を加えました。 加我国造→Kaganokuni no miyatsuko local lord of Kaga Province)と（）の説明を加えました。
sen.e: In the part of 'Tenno Hongi' (Records of emperors) of a text of Japanese histories "Sendai Kujihongi," he (Emperor Keitai) was born between Tanbanomichinoshi no kimi's daughter, Matonohime, and Emperor Suinin, and he was said to be the brother of Inawake no mikoto, and in the part of 'Kokuzo Hongi' (Records of kuni no miyatsuko [local lords]), he was said to be the ancestor of Hakuinokuni no miyatsuko (local lord of the Hakui Province) and Kaganokuni no miyatsuko (local lord of Kaga Province).
sen.cmt: Tennohonki→Tenno Hongi、Sendaikujihongi→Sendai Kujihongi、Kokuzohonki→Kokuzo Hongiとし、カッコ不足分追加
sen.e: In the part of 'Tenno Hongi' (Records of emperors) of a text of Japanese histories "Sendai Kujihongi," he (Emperor Keitai) was born between Tanbanomichinoshi no kimi's daughter, Matonohime, and Emperor Suinin, and he was said to be the brother of Inawake no mikoto, and in the part of 'Kokuzo Hongi' (Records of kuni no miyatsuko [local lords]), he was said to be the ancestor of Hakuinokuni no miyatsuko (local lord of the Hakui Province) and Kaganokuni no miyatsuko (local lord of Kaga Province).

sen.j: 命の子孫は高島郡高島村(滋賀県高島市拝戸)に住み、同地に水尾神社(延喜式内社・県社)を創建して磐撞別命を祀った。
sen.e: His decedents, who were living in Takashima-mura Village, Takashima Country (Haido, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture), constructed Mio-jinja Shrine (Engishikinaisha [shrine enlisted in Engishiki code])/県社Prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka) to enshrine Iwatsukuwake no mikoto.
sen.cmt: 延喜式内社→定訳不明：Engishikinaisha (shrine enlisted in Engishiki code)としました。 県社→Prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka)
sen.e: His decedents, who were living in Takashima Village, Takashima Country (Haido, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture), constructed Mio-jinja Shrine, which is Engishikinaisha (shrine enlisted in Engishiki code) and Kensha (prefectural shrine [of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka]), to enshrine Iwatsukuwake no mikoto.
sen.cmt: Takashima Villageとし、(延喜式内社・県社)の表記を修正NC_Check
sen.e: His decedents, who lived in Takashima Village, Takashima Country (Haido, Takashima City, Shiga Prefecture), constructed Mio-jinja Shrine, which is Engishikinaisha (shrine enlisted in Engishiki code) and Kensha (prefectural shrine [of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka]), to enshrine Iwatsukuwake no mikoto.
sen.cmt: who were living in→who lived in

sen.j: 水尾神社境内には磐衝別命墓があり、大正6年宮内省により陵墓に指定された。
sen.e: In the premise of Mio-jinja Shrine, there is the tomb of Iwatsukuwake no mikoto, which was designated as an Imperial Tomb by the Imperial Household Agency in 1917 (表記の変更).
On the premises of Mio-jinja Shrine, there is the tomb of Iwatsukuwake no mikoto, which was designated as an Imperial Tomb by the Imperial Household Agency in 1917.
sen.cmt: In the premise→On the premisesとし、訳文内の"(表記の変更)"削除
sen.e: On the premises of Mio-jinja Shrine, there is the tomb of Iwatsukuwake no mikoto, which was designated as an Imperial Tomb by the Imperial Household Agency in 1917.

sen.j: 水尾神社によると命は猿田彦命の天成神道を学ぶ為に同地に訪れ、同地で薨去した。
sen.e: According to the registration of Mio-jinja Shrine, he came over to that village to learn Amenarumichi Shinto that Sarutahiko no mikoto initiated, and he died there.
According to the registration of Mio-jinja Shrine, he came over to that village to learn Amenarumichi Shinto that Sarutahiko no mikoto initiated, and he died there.
According to the registration of Mio-jinja Shrine, he came over to that village to learn Amenarumichi Shinto that Sarutahiko no mikoto initiated, and he died there.

sen.j: 王子の磐城別王が三尾山に命を葬り水尾神社を創建したという。
sen.e: It is said that his son Prince Iwakiwake no miko buried him in Mt. Mio and constructed the Mio-jinja Shrine.
It is said that his son Prince Iwakiwake no miko buried him in Mt. Mio and constructed the Mio-jinja Shrine.
It is said that his son Prince Iwakiwake no miko buried him in Mt. Mio and constructed the Mio-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: 他に石川県羽咋市川原町の県社羽咋神社(延喜式内社)にも祀られている。
sen.e: In addition, Iwatsukuwake no mikoto is enshrined at Prefectural shrine Hakui-jinja Shrine (Engishikinaisha) in awara-machi, Hakui City, Ishikawa Prefecture.
In addition, Iwatsukuwake no mikoto is enshrined at Prefectural shrine Hakui-jinja Shrine (Engishikinaisha) in Kawara-machi, Hakui City, Ishikawa Prefecture.
In addition, Iwatsukuwake no mikoto is enshrined at Prefectural shrine Hakui-jinja Shrine (Engishikinaisha) in Kawara-machi, Hakui City, Ishikawa Prefecture.

sen.j: 羽咋市の無形文化財に指定されている唐戸山神事相撲は同地で仁政を敷いた命を偲んで命日である9月25日に相撲を行った事に由来するという。
sen.e: The origin of Karatoyama-shinji sumo in Hakui City, designated as an intangible cultural property, is said to be traced back to the event in which the people used to celebrate Sumo on the 25th day of the 9th month, every year to recall him and his good governance.
sen.cmt: 9月25日 →the 25th day of the 9th monthとしました。
sen.e: The origin of Karatoyama-shinji sumo in Hakui City, designated as an intangible cultural property, is said to be traced back to the event in which the people used to celebrate Sumo on the 25th day of the 9th month, the anniversary of Iwatsukuwake no mikoto's death, every year to recall him and his good governance.
sen.cmt: 「命日である」→訳漏れのため訳出
sen.e: The origin of Karatoyama-shinji sumo in Hakui City, designated as an intangible cultural property, is said to be traced back to the event in which the people used to celebrate Sumo on the 25th day of the 9th month, the anniversary of Iwatsukuwake no mikoto's death, every year to recall him and his good governance.

sen.j: また、羽咋の地名の由来は磐衝別命の故事によるという。
sen.e: And the name of the city, 'Hakui,' was said to have come from the following legend of Iwatsukuwake no mikoto.
And the name of the city, 'Hakui,' is said to have come from the following legend of Iwatsukuwake no mikoto.
sen.cmt: was said to have come→is said to have comeとしました。
sen.e: And the name of the city, 'Hakui,' is said to have come from the following legend of Iwatsukuwake no mikoto.

sen.j: 命はこの地で領民を苦しめた悪鳥を射落とし、その鳥の羽を命が連れていた三匹の犬が喰ったといい、古くは｢羽喰｣と称したという。
sen.e: According to the legend, the mikoto shut down an evil bird, who long troubled the people in the territory, and the three dogs he accompanied ate up its wings, and therefore, the place was used to be called 'Hakui' (eat wings).

According to the legend, the mikoto shut down an evil bird, who long troubled the people in the territory, and the three dogs he accompanied ate up its wings, and therefore, the place used to be called 'Hakui' (eat wings).
sen.cmt: was used to be called→used to be calledに修正
sen.e: According to the legend, the mikoto shut down an evil bird, who long troubled the people in the territory, and the three dogs he accompanied ate up its wings, and therefore, the place used to be called 'Hakui' (eat wings).

sen.j: 但し、一説には大国主命の故事によるともいう。
sen.e: However, another theory presents a different version, in which the name derived from an ancient event related to Okuninushi no mikoto.
sen.cmt: 大国主命の故事→定訳不明：an ancient event related to Okuninushi no mikotoとしました。
sen.e: However, another theory presents a different version, in which the name is derived from an ancient event related to Okuninushi no mikoto.
sen.cmt: the name derived→the name is derivedとしました。
sen.e: However, another theory presents a different version, in which the name is derived from an ancient event related to Okuninushi no mikoto.

sen.j: 子孫の振媛命は越前国(福井県)の出であるが、その福井県坂井市・大湊神社の古い記録によると嘗ては同神社に磐撞別命も祭神として祀っていたという。
sen.e: Furihime no mikoto, his descendent, was from Echizen Province (Fukui Prefecture), and according to an old document kept at Ominato-jinja Shrine in Sakai City, Fukui Prefecture, and in this shine, Iwatsukuwake no mikoto was also enshrined in the past as an enshrined deity.

Furihime no mikoto, his descendent, was from Echizen Province (Fukui Prefecture), and according to an old document kept at Ominato-jinja Shrine in Sakai City, Fukui Prefecture, Iwatsukuwake no mikoto was also enshrined in the past as an enshrined deity in this shrine.
sen.cmt: shrineのスペルミス修正、andを削除し、文末にin this shrine移動
sen.e: Furihime no mikoto, his descendent, was from Echizen Province (Fukui Prefecture), and according to an old document kept at Ominato-jinja Shrine in Sakai City, Fukui Prefecture, Iwatsukuwake no mikoto was also enshrined in the past as an enshrined deity in this shrine.
